author: ZarrCon
body:
One way I like to visualize dividend growth investing is by using Visa as an example. A lot of people might look at its current yield of 0.70% and think it would be a terrible dividend stock to own because they yield is so low. But when you look at the actual dividend amounts things start to become a lot more clear.

In 2009, Visa paid a dividend of $0.10 a share. In 2019 they paid a dividend of $1.00 a share. Visa's stock price was around $20 in 2009, so if we use that as our cost basis, the current dividend yield we'd be receiving from shares purchased in 2009 would be 5% (known as yield on cost). So basically even though Visa currently yields 0.70% to anyone buying today, that doesn't mean everyone holding shares is making 0.70% on their investment. 

This is one of the reasons Warren Buffet has been so successful over the years. For example, his cost basis on Coca Cola is $3.25 per share, and the stock currently pays a dividend of $1.64 per share. This means Buffet's yield on cost is over 50%. He invested $1.3B in KO back in the late 80s and early 90s, and will now collect $654 million in income from the stock this year alone.

author: ron_leflore
body:
You're probably better off investing in something like this https://angel.co/v/access-fund

They have their returns posted there for past funds.

The catch is (1) you kiss your money goodbye for 5-10 years, there's no practical way to sell early, and (2) the minimum investment is $100k or so.

author: Pijoto
body:
Hydrogen is the new Oil... Europe has so much offshore wind farms, they're now using the excess energy capacity to create hydrogen fuel.  Now China is racing ahead to try and dominate another growing industry...  It could also be that Europe and China no longer want to rely on a dirty fuel that's mainly produced by unstable and despotic regimes.... All while the US is being left behind, while supporting a dying industry.  If Biden wins, start investing in Hydrogen businesses... Gonna look into options tomorrow for the following:

Bloom Energy (NYSE:BE)

FuelCell Energy (NASDAQ:FCEL)

Plug Power (NASDAQ:PLUG)

Ballard Power Systems (NASDAQ:BLDP)


[‘Hydrogen Wars’ Pit Europe v. China for $700 Billion Business](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-11-01/-hydrogen-wars-pit-europe-v-china-for-700-billion-business)

author: ricke813
body:
Animal health stocks (IDXX and ZTS): Should accelerate growth in 2021 after restrictions are lifted and people are more comfortable going to the vet. See the earnings call for IDXX, revenue growth and vet visits are actually positive this year because despite the restrictions... people still care about their pets and more people WFH = more first time pet owners

LYV: What I learned is that most people don't care about social distancing and are ok with packing a venue to watch concerts and sports again. So many of the mom and pop shop venues are probably going to close due to $0 cash flow this year. As long as LYV can make it out alive until restrictions are lifted... the only competitor in there way will be pretty much AEG and they can continue its pre-COVID momentum. Warning... the stock hasn't dropped a lot for a company that is in a cash crunch and has +95% revenue decrease, which surprises me. E
What won't surprise me if the stock drops to $20 - $45 and I'll be a buyer.

V and MA: Should also accelerate growth once a vaccine is available and transactions are lifted. They should recover a big chunk of their spending volume and cross-border fees, but I think business travel is permanently impaired. Right now I'm a V holder, but I like PYPL a bit more as my favorite fintech.

author: snyder810
body:
I do think you’re right on how they’ll report, but the CDNs & fintech have been taking a beating. The upside seems to be a Visa reaction right now.

I cashed out both at 100% returns because I just didn’t see any more medium term upside given how fast they have grown when the market sentiment shifted. I think tech in general has entered a period where over the next few quarters the sentiment will be prove it to maintain, misstep at all and here’s your 20-30% fall. I hope I’m wrong, I like both companies, my strategy is just risk averse and willing sell when I feel uncomfortable with valuation. For the don’t time the market replies, that’s why the core of my own portfolio is buying the market with VOO & segment ETFs while augmenting with some select individuals. For any 0 div growth stocks I’m willing to cash out since they won’t compound at all should they stagnate or decline for an elongated period.
